body: ah, thanks, i was unaware of some of those. added [6]

@fehiepsi Do you have time to look into a pyro.ops.studentt analogous to pyro.ops.gaussian? I think a `pyro.distributions.StudentTHMM` would be a very competitive time series model if we can make the math work (say with common dof for all transition and emission distributions).

Note I'm not sure how much is possible, e.g. maybe we can only support univariate Student t.

@fritzo I have some discussions with @martinjankowiak previously about MVStudentT. Hope that it already settles all the math. I will see if it works in a few days (currently I am working on square root version of Gaussian).

aah unfortunately all those conversations were in the context of
variational interference (and so not directly applicable)

issue.title: Implement GaussianGamma op

repository.name: pyro
repository.description: Deep universal probabilistic programming with Python and PyTorch

issue.body:
This is a step towards having StudentT filters (see https://github.com/pyro-ppl/funsor/issues/190).

The main reference which I use is [1], which constructs an exact filter for scaled mixtures of normals and elliptically contoured distributions (which are more general than StudentT). I am not sure if this approach will work for us but it is the most promising one which I know. The idea is to introduce an auxiliary Gamma variable `s`, which we will keep updating the posteriors `p(x | s, y)` and `p(s | y)` during filtering process.

My intuition is to mimic how StudentT filter works
```
1. p(x_t-1 | y1,...,y_t-1, s) = Normal(m, sC), where p(s|y1,...y_t-1) = Gamma(a, b)
2. p(xt | y1,...,y_t-1, s) = Normal(..., sD)
3. p(yt | y1,...,y_t-1, s) = Normal(..., sE)
4. p(xt | y1,...,yt, s) = Normal(..., sF)
5. p(s | y1,...,yt) ~ p(s | y1,...,yt-1).p(yt=yt | y1...,y_t-1, s) = Gamma(a', b')
```
where steps 1-4 follow Kalman filter predict and update.

### Reference
1. [Bayesian Kalman Filtering with Elliptically Contoured Errors](https://www.jstor.org/stable/2336969?seq=1#page_scan_tab_contents)

### Done
- Implement trivial event methods: pad, permute, add

### Tasks (ordered according to its complexity)
- [x] Implement event_logsumexp
- [x] Implement condition
- [x] Implement marginalize
- [x] Add tests for the above methods
- [x] Implement matrix_and_mvt_to_GaussianGamma. An auxiliary Gamma variable `s` will be introduced so that p(x, s) is GaussianGamma and the marginal p(x) is StudentT.

Follow-up PR (this PR is already large)
- ~Test against the formula in the paper
[Student’s t-Filters for Noise Scale Estimation](https://users.aalto.fi/~ssarkka/pub/SPL2019.pdf)~ Edit: use `skip_multiplier_prior` flag for that model, no need to test because we can implement the same model

Hopefully all pieces will stick together. So we can use temporal parallelization for StudentT filter.

issue.title: Implement recognition of affine transforms

milestone.title: Initial release
milestone.description: Working implementations of the examples in the design doc as well as any necessary infrastructure

issue.body:
To perform full exact inference of Gaussian distributions, we will need some ability to recognize affine transforms. This might either rely on autograd, or could simply pattern match `+`, `*`, and einsum patterns.

## Tasks

- [x] Handle `Binary` and `Variable` patterns #116 
- [x] Rewrite `Normal(Affine, ...)` to an appropriate `Gaussian` #119 
- [x] Handle `Contract` and `einsum` #157 
- [x] Recognize affine funsors including `Contraction` and `Einsum` #249 
- [x] Recognize `GetitemOp` and `ReshapeOp` as a linear transformations #249 
- [x] Rewrite `MultivariateNormal(Affine, ...)` to an appropriate `Gaussian` #245
- [x] Fix `funsor.affine.is_affine()` to be sound but incomplete #282
- [x] Rewrite `Gaussian(x=affine)` as a `Gaussian`. In three steps: #284, #285, #286

issue.title: Implement GammaGaussianHMM

repository.name: pyro
repository.description: Deep universal probabilistic programming with Python and PyTorch

issue.body:
Addresses https://github.com/pyro-ppl/funsor/issues/190
~~Blocked by #2025~~

As a consequence of #2025, this PR implements a student-t filter which is exact and parallel scanned. Note that this requires the joint distribution of init_state, latent sites, obs sites is a StudentT distribution (hence, there is only one common degree of freedom). Relaxing this condition would require some sort of moment matching for tensordot op and would be non-exact.

### References

+ F. J. Giron and J. C. Rojano (1994) "Bayesian Kalman filtering with elliptically contoured errors"
+ Filip Tronarp, Toni Karvonen, and Simo Sarkka (2019)
   "Student's t-filters for noise scale estimation"
   https://users.aalto.fi/~ssarkka/pub/SPL2019.pdf

### TODO
- [x] double check `.filter()` method.
This method returns posteriors for both "multiplier" `s` and the final latent state, which should be enough for forecasting.
- [x] add tests similar to GaussianHMM for this class

Blocked by #2025

body: I think we could do this with an auxiliary variable reparameterizer like `pyro.poutine.reparam`. In funsor I believe this would be a `reparam` interpretation that could e.g. transform a `StudentT` or `Stable` to a `Joint` with other variables. I doubt we yet have the machinery for an end-to-end heavy-tailed HMM example, but that could probably be done in ~1 week of coding. See Pyro's [Forecasting II example](http://pyro.ai/examples/forecasting_ii.html#Heavy-tailed-modeling-with-LinearHMM).
